'''Gender-blind''' (or '''unisex''') is a term describing activities undertaken and services provided without regard to the [[gender]] of those who participate.
== Choice of words == {{weasel}} ''Unisex'' is an older term, and a [[misnomer]] meaning "one sex". Some feel it carries the connotation of being ''duo''-sex, (which would mean ''two at the same time'') and many being afraid to use the more appropriate term, ''bisex'', because of the sexual connotations. Whereas, ''gender-blind'' goes against most tenets of [[heteronormativity]], by not looking at gender at all.
== The National Student Genderblind Campaign ==
In 2006 the [http://www.genderblind.org National Student Genderblind Campaign] was created as a collaborative grass-roots organization intended to educate [[college]] students, administrators, and others throughout the country. The NSGC advocates for the implementation of gender-inclusive [[dormitory|dorm]] room and [[washroom|bathroom]] options.
The goal of the gender-blind dorm policy campaign is to allow roommates to be assigned without regard to any person’s sex. The backers of the proposal claim it would allow [[transgender]] people and people who do not accept gender labels to live in more comfortable settings than may otherwise be possible in single-sex housing.{{Fact|date=September 2007}} They also claim it is a good policy for [[heterosexual]]s who otherwise couldn't live with their partners while at the university.{{Fact|date=September 2007}}
In December 2006, the National Student Genderblind Campaign found itself in national controversy after receiving what it claimed to be biased and negligent coverage by Boston's Fox 25 News.<ref>[http://www.onlinegreensboro.com/~matthillnc/archives/1683 " National ‘gender-blind’ college housing student advocacy organization concerned with biased coverage," MattHillNC.com | The Q-triad Blog, December 13, 2006]</ref> The controversy triggered a formal press statement released nationally<ref>[http://www.genderblind.org/press121506slander.pdf NSGC Statement (PDF), December 15, 2006]</ref> and an appearance on Fox News Channel's "Heartland" show with John Kasich on December 16, 2006.
